  • High-Level API
    • Overview
    • Prerequisites
    • 1. Pipeline
      • a) Tabular Dataset
      • b) Sequence Dataset
      • c) Image Dataset
    • 2. Experiment
      • Model Functions
        • fn_build
        • fn_train
      • Hyperparameters
      • Experiment.make()
  • Low-Level API
    • Prerequisites
    • 1. Ingest a Dataset
      • Object Relational Model (ORM)
      • Persisting and Compressing Structured Data
      • Data Sources
        • Dataset.Tabular.from_pandas()
        • Dataset.Tabular.from_numpy()
        • Dataset.Tabular.from_path
        • Sequence Datasets
        • Dataset.Sequence.from_numpy()
        • Image Datasets
        • Dataset.Image.from_urls()
        • Dataset.Image.from_folder()
      • Reading Datasets
      • Dataset.Tabular.to_pandas()
      • Dataset.Tabular.to_numpy()
      • Dataset.Image.to_pillow()
      • Dataset.Image.to_numpy()
    • 2. Select the Label column(s).
      • ORM
      • Deriving Labels
      • Reading Labels
    • 3. Select the Feature column(s).
      • ORM
      • Specifying Features
      • Reading Features
    • 4. Optional, define sliding time series Windows.
      • ORM
      • Specifying Windows
      • Reading Windows
    • 5. Slice samples with a Splitset.
      • Stratification of continuous labels.
      • Splitting Strategies
        • a) Default supervised 70-30 split.
        • b) Specifying test size.
        • c) Specifying validation size.
        • d) Unsupervised
        • e) Take all samples for inference
      • Reading Splitsets
    • 6. Optionally, create a Foldset for cross-validation.
      • ORM
        • Fold objects
      • Specifying Foldsets
      • Reading Foldsets
        • Sample indices of each Fold:
    • 7. Optionally, encode labels with Labelcoder.
      • Encoding
      • Labelcoder
      • Creating a Labelcoder
    • 8. Optionally, encode Features sequentially with Featurecoder(s).
      • Background
      • Filtering feature columns
      • Creating an Encoderset and attaching multiple Featurecoders to it.
    • 9. Create an Algorithm aka model.
      • ORM
      • Model Definition
        • Function to build model
        • Optional, function to calculate loss.
        • Optional, function to optimize model.
        • Function to train model
        • Optional, function to predict samples
        • Group the functions together in an Algorithm!
    • 10. Optional, associate a Hyperparamset with your model.
      • Parameters are fed into Algorithm functions.
      • Hyperparameter Selection Strategies.
        • Grid search strategy.
        • Random selection strategy.
        • Bayesian selection strategy.
      • Hyperparamcombo objects.
    • 11. Create a Queue of training Jobs.
      • Job objects.
      • Execute all Jobs.
        • 1. queue.run_jobs(in_background=False)
        • 2. queue.run_jobs(in_background=True); experimental
        • 3. Future, distributed cloud execution.
    • 12. Preprocessing during Job is recorded
    • 13. Predictors are the trained models.
      • Fetching the trained model.
    • 14. Predictions are the output of a Predictor.
      • Fetching metrics.
    • 15. Metrics & Visualization
  • Inference
    • Predictor
    • New Splitset
    • Run Inference

About

  • Mission
    • Why Does AIQC Exist?
      • 1. Accelerate science by making deep learning accessible.
      • 2. Bring the scientific method to data science.
      • 3. Break down walled gardens to keep science open.

  • Keras: Classify Binary Times Series

Keras: Classify Binary Times SeriesÂ¶

Binary Detection of Epileptic Seizures Using a Cohort of Sequence of Electroencephalography (EEG) Readings.

Sequence data structures contain many observations (rows) for each sample (e.g.Â site, sensor, or patient). They are often used for grouping time-based observations into what is called a time series. However, sequences can also represent biological sequences like DNA and RNA.

The cardinality of many observations per sample changes the dimensionality of the data from 2D to 3D. This effectively adds an additional layer of complexity to all aspects of data preparation. In this notebook, youâll see that, once a Dataset.Sequence has been ingested, the AIQC API allows you to work with multivariate 3D data as easily as if it were 2D. As an example, you can still apply encoders by dtype and column_name.

[2]:

import aiqc
from aiqc import datum

Example DataÂ¶

[6]:

from aiqc import datum

[7]:

df = datum.to_pandas('epilepsy.parquet')

[8]:

df.head()

a) High-Level APIÂ¶

Reference High-Level API Docs for more information.

[9]:

label_df = df[['seizure']]

[10]:

seq_ndarray3D = df.drop(columns=['seizure']).to_numpy().reshape(1000,178,1)

[19]:

from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler

[18]:

splitset = aiqc.Pipeline.Sequence.make(

    seq_ndarray3D = seq_ndarray3D
    , seq_feature_encoders = [{
        "sklearn_preprocess": StandardScaler()
        , "columns": '0'
    }]

    , tab_DF_or_path = label_df
    , tab_label_column = 'seizure'

    , size_test = 0.22
    , size_validation = 0.12
)

   This saves memory when concatenating the output of many encoders.

[29]:

import keras
from keras.models import Sequential
from keras.layers import LSTM, Dense
from keras.callbacks import History

[20]:

def fn_build(features_shape, label_shape, **hp):
    model = Sequential()
    model.add(LSTM(
        hp['neuron_count']
        , input_shape=(features_shape[0], features_shape[1])
    ))
    model.add(Dense(units=label_shape[0], activation='sigmoid'))
    return model

[21]:

def fn_train(model, loser, optimizer, samples_train, samples_evaluate, **hp):
    model.compile(
        loss=loser
        , optimizer=optimizer
        , metrics=['accuracy']
    )
    model.fit(
        samples_train['features'], samples_train['labels']
        , validation_data = (samples_evaluate['features'], samples_evaluate['labels'])
        , verbose = 0
        , batch_size = hp['batch_size']
        , epochs = hp['epochs']
        , callbacks = [History()]
    )
    return model

[22]:

hyperparameters = {
    "neuron_count": [25]
    , "batch_size": [8]
    , "epochs": [5, 10]
}

[23]:

queue = aiqc.Experiment.make(
    library = "keras"
    , analysis_type = "classification_binary"
    , fn_build = fn_build
    , fn_train = fn_train
    , splitset_id = splitset.id
    , repeat_count = 2
    , hide_test = False
    , hyperparameters = hyperparameters

    , fn_lose = None #automated
    , fn_optimize = None #automated
    , fn_predict = None #automated
    , foldset_id = None
)

[24]:

queue.run_jobs()

ð® Training Models ð®: 100%|ââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââ| 4/4 [02:09<00:00, 32.27s/it]

For more information on visualization of performance metrics, reference the Visualization & Metrics documentation.

b) Low-Level APIÂ¶

[6]:

df = datum.to_pandas('epilepsy.parquet')

[7]:

label_df = df[['seizure']]

[8]:

seq_ndarray3D = df.drop(columns=['seizure']).to_numpy().reshape(1000,178,1)

[9]:

dataset_tabular = aiqc.Dataset.Tabular.from_pandas(label_df)

[10]:

label = dataset_tabular.make_label(columns='seizure')

[13]:

dataset_sequence = aiqc.Dataset.Sequence.from_numpy(
    ndarray_3D = seq_ndarray3D
    , column_names = ['EEG']
)

â±ï¸ Validating Sequences ð§¬: 100%|ââââââââââââ| 1000/1000 [00:00<00:00, 761493.10it/s]
â±ï¸ Ingesting Sequences ð§¬: 100%|ââââââââââââââââ| 1000/1000 [00:09<00:00, 110.77it/s]

[14]:

feature = dataset_sequence.make_feature()

[15]:

encoderset = feature.make_encoderset()

[20]:

encoderset = encoderset.make_featurecoder(
    sklearn_preprocess = StandardScaler()
    , columns = ['EEG']
)

[21]:

splitset = aiqc.Splitset.make(
    feature_ids = [feature.id]
    , label_id = label.id
    , size_test = 0.22
    , size_validation = 0.12
)

[22]:

def fn_build(features_shape, label_shape, **hp):
    model = Sequential()
    model.add(LSTM(
        hp['neuron_count']
        , input_shape=(features_shape[0], features_shape[1])
    ))
    model.add(Dense(units=label_shape[0], activation='sigmoid'))
    return model

[23]:

def fn_train(model, loser, optimizer, samples_train, samples_evaluate, **hp):
    model.compile(
        loss=loser
        , optimizer=optimizer
        , metrics=['accuracy']
    )
    model.fit(
        samples_train['features'], samples_train['labels']
        , validation_data = (samples_evaluate['features'], samples_evaluate['labels'])
        , verbose = 0
        , batch_size = hp['batch_size']
        , epochs = hp['epochs']
        , callbacks = [History()]
    )
    return model

[24]:

algorithm = aiqc.Algorithm.make(
    library = "keras"
    , analysis_type = "classification_binary"
    , fn_build = fn_build
    , fn_train = fn_train
)

[25]:

hyperparameters = {
    "neuron_count": [25]
    , "batch_size": [8]
    , "epochs": [5, 10]
}

[26]:

hyperparamset = algorithm.make_hyperparamset(
    hyperparameters = hyperparameters
)

[27]:

queue = algorithm.make_queue(
    splitset_id = splitset.id
    , hyperparamset_id = hyperparamset.id
    , repeat_count = 2
)

[30]:

queue.run_jobs()

ð® Training Models ð®: 100%|ââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââââ| 4/4 [02:13<00:00, 33.34s/it]

Reference Low-Level API Docs for more information including how to work with non-tabular data and defining optimizers.
